Tools

An evolving list of tools that I use (or getting better at, hence usually outdated) :

1. Operating System 

*NIX - If you're just a casual Internet user, any *nix system will give you far better browsing speeds than Windows. Plus, they're way more hacker-friendly. (I use Ubuntu) 

2. Browser

Google Chrome is the lightest and fastest browser I've used - and you can bet it's here to stay ! Firefox had it's hey-day a couple of years back. Right now, it's all about Chrome.
Honorary Mention: Mozilla Firefox, the grand-pa of IE competitors.

3. Blogging Engine 

Wordpress has one of the greatest collection of plugins and themes you find, not to mention the quality of the community that maintains it. Ask Microsoft.
Honorary Mention: Drupal is an open source CMS.

4. Anonymity 

Tor gives me peace of mind when I watch educational videos, download legitimate torrents and don't go about being an XSS noob. I just activate Tor  on-the-fly and go ahead.
Honorary Mention: HideMyAss does what it says.

5. Music 

Grooveshark is the best way to listen to free, on-demand, legal music. No arguments.
Honorary Mention : Pandora (though you need to use a VPN to access outside US)

6. Search Engine 

DuckDuckGo is built by a kick-ass developer over Yahoo BOSS. It's awesome especially for programmers, and pretty much everyone else.
Honorary Mention: Google. Need I say more?

7. Backup 

Dropbox acts as my damage-limitation exercise for my aging laptop. It 'just works'.
Honorary Mention : Ubuntu One.

8. Torrents 

Demonoid has all those awesome legitimate torrents I was talking about, not to be found elsewhere. Honorary Mention: Torrific is the DDG of torrent search.

9. Twitter Client 

DestroyTwitter is the lightest and coolest twitter client ever. It also makes sure I don't miss #NewTwitter.
Honorary Mention: The big-n-bulky TweetDeck

10. Ad-Blocker 

Still looking at banner ads? Get AdSweep for Chrome ! Destroys banner ads!
Honorary and geeky mention :  Kill Your Ads with an Asteroid-style spaceship ! Only for fun.

10. Twitter Chat 

Here's a massive collection of over 200 Twitter Chats you can take part in. Don't just listen, but participate too!

11. Download Manager 

Internet Download Manager is the fastest download accelerator on the planet. Still looking for a Linux version :(
Honorary Mention: wget

12. Videos 

Radbox helps you save and queue videos to watch later. Everything has a place and a time.
Honorary Mention: YouTube

13. Feed Reader 

Google Reader makes sure you read your content in a great environment, stripped of annoying ads.

14. Bookmarks 

Instapaper rules ! 
Honorary Mention: Delicious

15. Avoid Procrastination 

StayFocused is a Chrome Plugin that restricts your procrastination tendencies.
Honorary Mention: Your own determination.

16. Thought-Provoking Stuff 

Harvard Business Review and The Economist are winners here, but don't get put off by their titles. It's way more than just economic/business jargon.

17. Web-Tools Collection 

This has to be one of the biggest collection of web-based tools anyone worth his salt could use.

18. Website Uptime 

Is your host giving you down-time and you don't even know about it ? WasItUp makes sure you always know.

19. Live Scores 

LiveScore makes sure you follow your favorite sports teams, even if they play for the Liga Nacional de Fútbol in Guatemala.

20. Comedy 

FailBlog never fails to make me laugh out loud. ( Don't OD on it, your stomach may burst from the laughter)

|=0|2 [0[)3|25

Editor (not online, but anyway)

I'll admit it, I'm no expert in Vim but the sheer power it gives you is unbelievable. I checked out emacs but it didn't really suit me.

Code Collaboration

CollabEdit is a simple solution for real-time code sharing , along with syntax highlighting.

OpenSource Projects

FreshMeat helps you choose an open-source project to contribute to. Get Started!
Honorary Mention : Github,Sourceforge

News

Hacker News has proved to the best place you can find the latest news about hackers and startups (For a preview, here's a partial best-of archive).
Honorary Mention : TechCrunch

Web-Startups

This Spreadsheet has the biggest collection of web-startups I've ever seen. Most of the new ones are still in beta and begging for you to take them for a spin. Help these startups shape the future of the Internet!

Forum

StackOverflow will beat any forum you use for your queries in response time and quality of answers. Period.

Programming Books

Presenting, one of the best resources of free (and legal) programming books, courtesy StackOverflow.
Honorary Mention : A list of must-read now no longer active, only on archive.org.

Tutorials (Web-Technologies)

NetTuts has some really awesome tutorials for most web-technologies. Targeted towards beginners-intermediates.

Hacker Jargon

Eric Raymond provides the complete reference, and even a how-to.

Multi-utility Bookmarklets

Quix gives you 'bookmarklets on steroids' . There's very little you can't do with them.
